Breast cancer is the most prevalent cancer among females worldwide including Sudan. The aim of this study was to determine the spatial distribution of breast cancer in Sudan.A facility based cross-sectional study was implemented in eighteen histopathology laboratories distributed in the three localities of Khartoum State on a sample of 4630 Breast Cancer cases diagnosed during the period 2010-2016. A master database was developed through Epi InfoTM 7.1.5.2 for computerizing the data collected: the facility name, type (public or private), and its geo-location (latitude and longitude). Personal data on patients were extracted from their respective medical records (name, age, marital status, ethnic group, state, locality, administrative unit, permanent address and phone number, histopathology diagnosis). The data was summarized through SPSS to generate frequency tables for estimating prevalence and the geographical information system (ArcGIS 10.3) was used to generate the epidemiological distribution maps. ArcGIS 10.3 spatial analysis features were used to develop risk maps based on the kriging method.Breast cancer prevalence was 3.9 cases per 100,000 female populations. Of the 4423 cases of breast cancer, invasive breast carcinoma of no special type (NST) was the most frequent (79.5%, 3517/4423) histopathological diagnosis. The spatial analysis indicated as high risk areas for breast cancer in Sudan the States of Nile River, Northern, Red Sea, White Nile, Northern and Southern Kordofan.The attempt to develop a predictive map of breast cancer in Sudan revealed three levels of risk areas (risk, intermediate and high risk areas); regardless the risk level, appropriate preventive and curative health interventions with full support from decision makers are urgently needed.

Background Primaquine is recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO) for radical treatment of Plasmodium vivax malaria. This drug is known to provoke acute hemolytic anemia in individuals with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. Due to lack of data on G6PD deficiency, the use of primaquine has been limited in Africa. In the present study, G6PD deficiency was investigated in blood donors of various ethnic groups living in Nouakchott, a P. vivax endemic area in Mauritania. Methodology/Principal findings Venous blood samples from 443 healthy blood donors recruited at the National Transfusion Center in Nouakchott were screened for G6PD activity using the CareStart G6PD deficiency rapid diagnostic test. G6PD allelic variants were investigated using DiaPlexC G6PD genotyping kit that detects African (A-) and Mediterranean (B-) variants. Overall, 50 of 443 (11.3%) individuals (49 [11.8%] men and 1 [3.7%] woman) were phenotypically deficient. Amongst men, Black Africans had the highest prevalence of G6PD deficiency (15 of 100 [15%]) and White Moors the lowest (10 of 168, [5.9%]). The most commonly observed G6PD allelic variants among 44 tested G6PD-deficient men were the African variant A- (202A/376G) in 14 (31.8%), the Mediterranean variant B- (563T) in 13 (29.5%), and the Betica-Selma A- (376G/968C) allelic variant in 6 (13.6%). The Santamaria A- variant (376G/542T) and A variant (376G) were observed in only one and two individuals, respectively. None of the expected variants was observed in 8 (18.2%) of the tested phenotypically G6PD-deficient men. Conclusion This is the first published data on G6PD deficiency in Mauritanians. The prevalence of phenotypic G6PD deficiency was relatively high (11.3%). It was mostly associated with either African or Mediterranean variants, in agreement with diverse Arab and Black African origins of the Mauritanian population.

While most of the existing class stability assessors just rely on structural information retrieved from a desired source code snapshot. However, class stability is intrinsically characterized by the evolution of a number of dependencies and change propagation factors which aid to promote the ripple effect. Identification of classes prone to ripple effect (instable classes) through mining the version history of change propagation factors can aid developers to reduce the efforts needed to maintain and evolve the system. We propose Historical Information for Class Stability Prediction (HICSP), an approach to exploit change history information to predict the instable classes based on its correlation with change propagation factors. Subsequently, we performed two empirical studies. In the first study, we evaluate the HICSP on the version history of 10 open source projects. Subsequently, in the second replicated study, we evaluate the effectiveness of HICSP by tuning the parameters of its stability assessors. We observed the 4 to 16 percent improvement in term of F-measure value to predict the instable classes through HICSP as compared to existing class stability assessors. The promising results indicate that HICSP is able to identify instable classes and can aid developers in their decision making.

Reward delay impulsivity is a feature of attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and a likely feature of loss of control eating (LOC-E), which might explain the higher risk of children with ADHD or LOC-E to become obese. The goal of this study was to investigate reward delay impulsivity in children with LOC-E, ADHD, or a double diagnosis, in contrast to healthy children. Children (8 to 13 years) with LOC-E (n = 24), ADHD (n = 33), a double diagnosis (n = 9), and healthy children (n = 34) performed a computer game (door opening task [DOT]) and the delay of gratification task (DoGT) to assess food related facets of reward delay impulsivity. In addition, children reported whether they worried to lose control over eating during the DoGT. There were no group differences in the DOT. However, children with ADHD or a double diagnosis had a significantly higher risk to eat prematurely during the DoGT than children with LOC-E, who were not significantly different from healthy children. Children with a double diagnosis were most likely to worry about losing control over eating during the DoGT, followed by children with LOC-E, and both had a significantly higher probability to worry than healthy children. For children with a double diagnosis the probability to worry was significantly higher than for children with ADHD. If replicated, these findings point to a special relevance of reward delay impulsivity in children with ADHD or a double diagnosis, compared to children with LOC-E. ADHD should be regularly assessed in children with LOC-E.

Lipocalins represent the most important protein family of the mammalian respiratory allergens. Four of the seven named dog allergens are lipocalins: Can f 1, Can f 2, Can f 4, and Can f 6. We present the structure of Can f 6 along with data on the biophysical and biological activity of this protein in comparison with other animal lipocalins. The Can f 6 structure displays the classic lipocalin calyx-shaped ligand binding cavity within a central β-barrel similar to other lipocalins. Despite low sequence identity between the different dog lipocalin proteins, there is a high degree of structural similarity. On the other hand, Can f 6 has a similar primary sequence to cat, horse, mouse lipocalins as well as a structure that may underlie their cross reactivity. Interestingly, the entrance to the ligand binding pocket is capped by a His instead of the usually seen Tyr that may help select its natural ligand binding partner. Our highly pure recombinant Can f 6 is able to bind to human IgE (hIgE) demonstrating biological antigenicity.

Homeodomain-interacting protein kinases (HIPKs) are kinases that phosphorylate transcription factors involved in cell proliferation, differentiation, and apoptosis. Their structures have been long sought because of their potential as drug targets in cancers and fibrosis. Agnew and colleagues present the first crystal structure of the HIPK2 kinase domain, complexed with the small-molecule inhibitor CX-4945, revealing important structural differences from related protein kinases of the DYRK family. This structure provides a starting point to exploit HIPK2's distinct structural features to develop selective small-molecule inhibitors of this kinase.

Background In Peru, there is an ongoing high-incidence HIV epidemic among men who have sex with men (MSM) and transgender women (TW). Sexual concurrency, or having sex with a partner in between two acts of sex with another partner, may be a key factor in onward HIV transmission. In this study, we quantify concurrency, evaluate factors associated with concurrency, and assess condom use with concurrent partners among MSM and TW in Peru. Methods We conducted a secondary analysis of data from the 2011 Peruvian Biobehavioral Survey. Pearson’s Chi-squared test was used to identify individual-level characteristics associated with concurrency. We estimated the association between participant characteristics, concurrent partnerships, partnership type (stable vs. non-stable), and CLAI within the context of concurrent partnerships using multivariate and repeated-measure Poisson regression. Results 3-month cumulative prevalence of concurrency was higher among TW compared to MSM (30.7% vs 25.2%, p = 0.014). Among those with concurrent stable and non-stable partners, 45% used condoms with both partners (95% CI: 40%-50%) and 30% preferentially had CLAI with the stable partner only (95%CI: 26%-35%). Factors associated with CLAI within the context of concurrent partnerships varied between MSM and TW. Conclusions Although concurrency is common among TW and MSM in Peru, patterns of concurrency and differential condom use may vary between TW and MSM. Future research may explore differential condom use with stable and non-stable partners to better understand behavioral factors that may alter vulnerability to HIV in TW compared to MSM.

Receiving the Lasker award for Clinical Medical Research is a staggering event. Perhaps equally staggering is the fact that as many as 2 million women worldwide have now been treated with Herceptin (trastuzumab), many of whom benefited from the treatment. This accomplishment is wonderfully rewarding for everyone who has been involved. Receiving the Lasker award for Clinical Medical Research is a staggering event. Perhaps equally staggering is the fact that as many as 2 million women worldwide have now been treated with Herceptin (trastuzumab), many of whom benefited from the treatment. This accomplishment is wonderfully rewarding for everyone who has been involved. There is a particular event that started us down this road. In about 1984, I learned that brain cancer is often treated by local surgery and then administration of a drug ironically called BCNU (bis-chloroethylnitrosourea) to the disease site. This drug can increase survival time, but quality of life is not good. There are many papers describing the mechanism of action of this drug (e.g., alkylating agent), but all it really does is dissolve tissue. At that time, I was just setting up my new lab at Genentech, and we believed we could do a lot better. Our goal became to find cancer targets that were particularly important and specific to cancer cells but irrelevant to normal cells. This, of course, is a recapitulation of Paul Ehrlich’s efforts of about 120 years ago. Ehrlich proposed the “magic bullet” concept. His hypothesis, later borne out by his discovery of the first effective anti-syphilis drug (salvarsan), was that it should be possible to kill specific microbes (such as bacteria) without harming the body itself. The magic bullet concept has been extended to include cancer, partly because Ehrlich learned that certain dyes could stain one type of cell differently than another type of cell. Ehrlich also formulated the first structural concept of an antibody, another topic that is obviously linked to our breakthrough with trastuzumab. He shared the 1908 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine with Élie Metchnikoff, whose discovery of macrophages contributed to the beginnings of cellular immunology. Metchnikoff’s discovery also figures importantly in our work with the TNF part of the trastuzumab story, as I will describe below. Our lab began by looking for some handle on an early event that distinguished tumor cells from normal cells. We were focusing on the mechanism of action of tumor necrosis factor (TNF). TNF, as it relates to cancer, was discovered by Lloyd Old at Sloan Kettering as a tumor cytotoxin in the sera of mice that had been treated with endotoxin. When the “toxic serum” was injected into mice with the MethA sarcoma, Old observed dramatic tumor hemorrhagic necrotizing effects, thus the name “TNF.” There were not a lot of other tumor types that could be tested by Old at that time, so most of his data related only to MethA sarcoma. Old's TNF proved elusive to purify and was not characterized until its molecular cloning by David Goeddel’s laboratory in 1984. Using this newly available reagent, Barry Sugarman, who was a postdoctoral fellow in my laboratory, characterized its effects on the proliferation of normal and tumor cell lines. Surprisingly, about two-thirds of tumor cell lines were already resistant to growth inhibition by TNF. Thus, TNF resistance was a common characteristic shared by many tumor cell lines and, therefore, might be an early property of aggressive tumors. This was substantiated by results obtained in collaboration with Hans Schreiber at the University of Chicago. In these experiments, we showed that a major mechanism through which macrophages attack early-stage tumors is through secretion of TNF. For these experiments, we used an ultraviolet-induced tumor cell line called UV-1591. Normally, UV-1591 will grow subcutaneously and then regress (Figure 1, blue box). Residual tumor cells will often then begin a second round of tumor growth, which is very rapidly progressive, until T cell immunity induces a second regression (Figure 1, blue circle). Remarkably, the difference between the regressing tumors (UV-1591-RE) and the rapidly progressing ones (UV-1591-PRO) is that, when tested in vitro, UV-1591-RE cells are sensitive to macrophage killing, while the UV-1591-PRO cells are resistant to macrophage killing. Thus, at least in this model system, TNF resistance is an early marker of a more aggressive tumor type. In nude mice that lack both active macrophages and T cells, both UV-1591-RE and -PRO grow rapidly (Figure 1, right). Further experiments showed that macrophage sensitivity or resistance in UV-1591 correlated with TNF sensitivity or resistance. These results are consistent with the hypothesis that tumor cells must get past the macrophage/TNF hurdle before they can progress further. Another surprising observation that we made at this time, in work spearheaded by Gail Lewis Phillips and Barry Sugarman, was that once TNF-sensitive tumor cells are selected for resistance to the cytokine, they are subsequently growth stimulated by it! This is an extraordinary example of the ways in which a tumor cell can adapt to its microenvironment, change its signaling pattern, and continue to benefit from host-supplied factors, even though those same factors had at one time held them in check. When we started this work in 1985, not much was known about the biology of TNF and its receptors. Trying to understand what might make sensitive cells resistant to TNF’s cytotoxic effects required some thought. We reasoned that autocrine or paracrine production of growth factors by the tumor cells themselves might be involved, since this was already a known phenomenon, first articulated by Sporn and Todaro. Following up on his earlier work, Barry Sugarman tested this hypothesis on TNF-sensitive tumor cells and found that adding growth factors that stimulated receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) to the cell-culture media could give 95% inhibition of TNF killing of otherwise TNF-sensitive tumor cells (Figure 2A ; Sugarman et al., 1987Sugarman B.J. Lewis G.D. Eessalu T.E. Aggarwal B.B. Shepard H.M. Effects of growth factors on the antiproliferative activity of tumor necrosis factors.Cancer Res. 1987; 47: 780-786PubMed Google Scholar). This result suggested that one mechanism of resistance to TNF is likely through the presence of growth factors and the tumor-cell-associated RTKs activated by them. Two other events were about to happen that would give us a possible path to create a therapy for cancer that would preferentially target tumors. The first thing to happen was when a postdoctoral fellow in Axel Ullrich’s laboratory, Robert Hudziak, heard me give a talk about our current work on TNF resistance. Late that night, Robert came to talk to me. Hudziak said he was very excited to hear our TNF story and our hypothesis that resistance to TNF might be mediated by RTKs. He went further to tell me that he had a receptor tyrosine kinase that we should use as a model system, which was HER2 (cloned in 1985 by Axel Ullrich’s group). We immediately began collaborating to test whether HER2 overexpression could blunt the cytotoxic effects of TNF. We utilized a set of cell lines, starting with TNF-sensitive 3T3 cells, that were engineered to express increasing amounts of HER2. We found that increasing HER2-associated tyrosine kinase activity correlated with increased resistance to both TNF and activated macrophages (Figure 2B). This was not just due to the transformed phenotype, because transformation of 3T3 cells by the RAS oncogene had no effect on their sensitivity to TNF. Later, it was also found by Hudziak that spontaneously transformed 3T3 cells overexpressed the c-met protooncogene and that they also have accompanying increased resistance to TNF, and similarly, selection of 3T3 cells with TNF resulted in transformed 3T3 cells with amplified c-met. These experiments suggested that HER2 may not be a special case. The next important event was a meeting at Genentech with Dennis Slamon, who, in collaboration with Axel Ullrich and William McGuire (University of Texas, San Antonio), had found that overexpression of HER2 predicted shortened survival for breast and ovarian cancer patients. With this knowledge, and with our work relating to TNF in hand, we thought that perhaps we knew why overexpression of HER2 resulted in worsened outcomes, that is, by blunting host antitumor surveillance by macrophages. The last important proof that we sought was whether the TNF resistance observed with HER2 overexpression could be modulated by an antibody antagonist of HER2. A large family of anti-HER2 monoclonal antibodies had been made by Hudziak and Bryan Fendly. In my lab, Gail Lewis Phillips, in a colossal effort, ranked the antibodies for their ability to inhibit the growth of tumor cells expressing escalating amounts of HER2. Importantly, she found that an exponential curve best fit the ability of the antibodies to inhibit growth of tumor cells. In practical terms, this meant that cells that expressed low amounts of HER2 (like most normal cells) were not growth inhibited by the antibody, but with 30-fold increased HER2 expression, tumor cells became sensitive to anti-HER2 monoclonal antibodies. Furthermore, the ability of the antibodies to induce TNF sensitivity was similarly dependent upon overexpression of HER2. Thus, the idea of biomarker (HER2 overexpression)-driven therapy for breast cancers was born. The antibody that most reproducibly inhibited the growth of HER2-overexpressing cells was called MuMAb4D5 (murine monoclonal antibody 4D5). It was this antibody we chose for most of our experimental work going forward. Probably the most important experiment we could do at this point in the project was to test whether incubation of 4D5 with HER2-overexpressing breast cancer cells could induce a cytotoxic response to TNF. This experiment was performed using SK-BR-3 tumor cells, which overexpress HER2. We found that these tumor cells were growth inhibited by either 4D5 or TNF alone. However, when they were combined, we observed cell killing. Thus, we knew that not only could HER2 induce resistance to TNF but also that downregulation of HER2 could induce TNF sensitivity. There were, however, still substantial scientific hurdles to overcome. The most difficult theoretical hurdle was the feeling at the time that monoclonal antibodies could not gain access to tumors as a result of high tumor interstitial pressure and the net outflow of fluid from within tumors. This was a serious objection, supported by the work of Rakesh Jain at MIT. Thus, it made sense to test whether an antibody administered to a patient could find its way to a HER2-overexpressing tumor and accumulate at that site. In an amazing experiment, that makes me dizzy even now, Genentech invested about $3 million into an effort to test this hypothesis. We made clinical-grade MuMAb4D5, filed an Investigational New Drug application, and proceeded with the antibody to UCLA. At UCLA, in the basement, Dan Maneval radiolabeled the antibody. Dennis Slamon then injected the antibody into the first patients, who had HER2-overexpressing tumors. Autoradiograms were made of the patients at several time points, and we found that the antibody made it to the tumor sites (correlated with known tumor locations) and accumulated there. Of course, the second big issue was whether MuMAb4D5 instigated an immune response to itself, an event that would make repeated treatments difficult. Indeed, we found that MuMAb4D5 was immunogenic, and this problem went unresolved at the Christmas break in 1990–1991. It now seemed to us, a team of highly charged partisans (“HERetics,” see Figure 3), that we had just one more hurdle to overcome: the issue of immunogenicity of the antibody. This was attacked with vigor in an all-consuming effort. In just 6 weeks, the murine antibody was cloned and sequenced, and Paul Carter made a set of humanized 4D5 variants using a technique he named “six pack mutagenesis,” which enabled both heavy and light chains to be humanized simultaneously. Nothing like this had ever been done before. Another thing that had never been done before was to express antibodies in a standard cell line like Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells. Undeterred by this, Cori Gorman took Carter’s clones, put them into a mammalian expression vector, and proceeded to make humanized 4D5 (rHuMAb4D5) in culture. Gail Lewis Phillips was on hand to show that one of Carter’s variants was even a little better than its murine parent at inhibiting the growth of HER2-overexpressing breast cancer cells, and Refaat Shalaby showed that rHuMAb4D5 was competent for antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity, but only on HER2-overexpressing tumor cells. This antibody ultimately became known as trastuzumab, or Herceptin. Faced with this fait acompli, our colleagues in management felt it was worth nominating the project for a full-fledged clinical effort. This is a very short description of the early days of trastuzumab. There were many administrative and business hurdles that needed to be overcome as well as the scientific hurdles I have mentioned. Trastuzumab was the first approved fully humanized monoclonal antibody, first approved inhibitor of a tyrosine kinase, first drug for cancer to be approved based upon biomarker-driven clinical trials (work largely guided by Bob Cohen at Genentech), and first antibody approved for the treatment of solid tumors. There were other biomarker-driven projects in the pipeline of pharma companies at this time, especially imatinib (Gleevec), championed by Brian Druker. Following the approval of trastuzumab, several of these drugs moved forward rapidly. Despite the novelty of trastuzumab, it was approved only 6 years after the first patient was treated, which is fast by any measure of recent drug development efforts in cancer. The most important lessons to be learned from the trastuzumab story are the tremendous value of dedicated teams of visionary researchers determined to make a difference in the world and the value of collaborations between scientists in all kinds of private and public institutions. As an outline of how this worked in the case of Herceptin, the story includes people like Robert Weinberg at MIT, who discovered that RTKs could be oncogenes; Axel Ullrich at Genentech, who shares this Lasker Award; Arthur Levinson, another Genentech scientist who shared reagents with Axel that enabled the cloning of HER2; David Goeddel, who led the Genentech team to clone and express human TNF; Bob Cohen, who developed the original companion diagnostic at Genentech; and Dennis Slamon and Mark Pegram of UCLA and Larry Norton at Sloan Kettering, the first clinical champions, as well as the many other clinicians and patients who took part in the clinical trials. Finally, I should mention the leadership of Robert Swanson, who co-founded Genentech with Herb Boyer. Many times Robert Swanson told me, as he told all the scientists at Genentech, that we should “follow our noses.” Without this kind of support for research aimed at improving human health, the trastuzumab project could never have happened. This was an incredible experience, and I was very lucky to have had a hand in it.

Oil impacting the northern Gulf of Mexico shoreline from the 2010 Deepwater Horizon accident was predominantly in the form of water-in-oil emulsions (WOE), a chemically weathered, highly viscous, neutrally buoyant material. Once formed, WOE are extremely difficult to destabilize. Commercially-available oil dispersants are largely ineffective de-emulsifiers as a result of the inability of dispersant surfactants to displace asphaltenes stabilizing the oil-water interface. This study investigated the effectiveness of the commercially-available dispersant Corexit 9500A, modified to enhance its polar fraction, in destabilizing WOE. Results suggest that Corexit modified to include between 20–60% fractional amount of either polar additive (1-octanol or hexylamine) will produce a modest increase in WOE instability, with a Corexit to hexylamine ratio of approximately 80/20 providing the most effective enhanced destabilization. Results support the hypothesis that modifying the fraction of polar constituents in commercial dispersants will increase asphaltene solubility, decrease oil-water interface stability, and enhance WOE instability.

Background In Côte d’Ivoire, people living with HIV (PLHIV) have free access to antiretroviral therapy (ART) and cotrimoxazole. Yet, they may use other medications to treat non-HIV diseases. Scarce data are available regarding the use of non-HIV medications in Africa. This study describes the use of non-HIV medications and identifies the factors associated with their use by PLHIV on ART in Côte d’Ivoire. Methods A cross-sectional study was conducted in six HIV clinics in 2016. HIV-1-infected adults receiving ART for at least one year were eligible. A standardized questionnaire was used to collect demographics, HIV characteristics and medication use data. Associated factors were identified using a multivariate adjusted Poisson regression. Results A total of 1,458 participants (74% women) were enrolled. The median age was 44 years, and the median duration of ART was 81 months. A total of 696 (48%) participants reported having used at least one non-HIV medication. Among the 1,519 non-HIV medications used, 550 (36%) had not been prescribed and 397 (26%) were from the nervous system class. Individuals who were more likely to report the use of at least one non-HIV medication included those who had been treated in an Abidjan HIV clinic, had a high school education level, had a monthly income between 152 and 304 euros, had a poor perceived health status, had WHO advanced clinical stage, had used traditional medicine products and had not used cotrimoxazole. Conclusion Almost half PLHIV on ART reported using non-HIV medication. Further research is needed to assess whether the use of non-HIV medication is appropriate given about a third of those medications are not being prescribed.

His work set the stage for current "givens" like genetic stratification of patients for treatment and using antibodies as therapeutics. Immunology is one of the most rapidly evolving and interdisciplinary fields in the biological sciences. We keep learning about new immune cell types; their curious origins; and the seemingly fundamental roles they play in cancer, metabolism, the central nervous system, and beyond. It may seem surprising, but just a few decades ago, scientists knew little about what kinds of cells defined our immune defenses and their developmental origins. The 2019 Albert Lasker Basic Medical Research Award recognizes the contributions of Max D. Cooper and Jacques Miller for their discovery of B and T lymphocytes and for paving the path toward modern immunology. Cell's Sri Narasimhan had a conversation with Max Cooper about the early days in the field, his journey, and the road ahead.
